author: Domino Development
comment:
Very interesting, and I also think important, video! I especially like the ideas regarding the pause, as well as the control and intention of it. In media I'd been used to observing people replying swiftly and talking rapidly. Some of these I regarded as competent people, conditioning me to communicate similarly to them. It's when I started digesting more auditive long-form philosophical and educational material that I realized the power of the pause; taking some extra time to think through both the content and delivery. 

Here are my thoughts of how I became, and still practice to become, more articulate. To preface; I think it mostly comes down to thinking, and writing is more formalized thinking, whereas speaking is more spontaneous thinking. Therefore, practicing thinking and writing also improves fundamental elements of speaking. 

I think that writing helps immensely in the pursuit of becoming more articulate. While this provides me with a bit of a safety net; to remember material I've written when I'm speaking, it mainly helps me practice more advanced articulations, since I have more time to think, and also research. Even this very comment will help me out when discussing articulating ones speech; I've now thought through what I've done to achieve a higher degree of language articulation, and I've now stored some documented notes of it in a database of my writing which I can go back and review. 

One thing that I do, as a bilinguist who thinks in two languages, is to practice translating words and expressions. I'm usually able to quickly express something in one of these languages, or at least when combining the two, but I want this translation to be as frictionless as possible. A translating tool can be useful for this purpose. I mostly do this when I'm thinking, but it also occurs when I'm writing. Aside from translating tools, when I'm writing I also have a dictionary from the respective language ready. In this way I can look up synonyms and antonyms for certain words; allowing me to choose a more rhythmic or impactful word for the text,  and to form connections between words so that I'm increasingly able to do the same when speaking.

Finally - and you touched on this in the video - putting yourself in situation where you're consuming and creating articulate material can be invaluable. Instead of a lot of mainstream music or content, digest that complicated podcast or lecture, or let your thoughts be the soundtrack. Enter the library, sit down in front of the typewriter, engage in social situations. I'm very blessed to now be in a position where I can constantly choose quality input and activities regarding developing one's ability to articulate language - and in turn articulate one's being. There are reasons for Newspeak in Orwell's 1984...

author: Ajm Jabir
comment:
The speaker in the YouTube video discusses five qualities that articulate speakers understand to enhance their speech:

>Expanding Surface Lexicon: Articulate speakers broaden their surface vocabulary by using words from their deep lexicon (less frequently used words) to convey ideas more vividly and expressively. This involves using words that might not be in their default vocabulary.

>Commanding the Pause: Effective use of pauses in speech allows speakers to create impact, emphasize key points, and give themselves time to organize their thoughts. Pausing showcases intentionality and confidence in speech.

>Pruning Filler Words: Articulate speakers consciously reduce filler words like "um," "ah," and "like" to make their speech more precise and deliberate. This requires mindful monitoring of speech patterns and habits.

>Language Inputs Inventory: Being mindful of the language sources one is exposed to, such as books, media, and conversations, helps in improving speech quality. Engaging with rich and articulate language sources enhances one's vocabulary and speaking skills.

>Tuning Vocal Instrument: A melodic and varied voice adds depth and impact to speech. By adjusting pitch, volume, speed, and variation, speakers can make their words more engaging and appealing, akin to music.

The video suggests that by practicing these five techniques, individuals can develop greater articulacy, leading to more expressive, persuasive, and engaging speech.

author: Walter Kemp Bruce
comment:
This is pretty constructive, but at risk of influencing people toward something much worse than verbosity: being a wanker. 

Honestly, if you're thinking "wow, I sound so articulate," chances are, your interlocutor isn't in agreement. It's much more likely that they're subconsciously aware of your thought process. In other words, it's less "wow, this person is so articulate," and more "wow, this person thinks they're so articulate."  Those are very, very different states. 

Typically, when I notice someone playing this game with their social performance, it signals a lack of intelligence and social awareness to me. The ability to express yourself clearly is more important than using rare and specific words, especially if the chances are that your listener won't understand them. It's also much less important than expressing good ideas, which is the only real context to be impressed by eloquence. 

I have a real tendency towards this kind of frilly speech. Growing up in a British context, surrounded by writers and semi-intellectual bourgeoisie, I was always told to clam it. "You sound like a wanker." It was the best advice I could've been given. Probably. 

I will say, to play devils advocate, that I've always loved Darren McGarvey's fluency as an orator. The combination of his thick Glasgow accent and the most articulate speech I've ever heard is quite compelling. I recommend him to anyone interested in examples of gifted self-expression. 

Anyway, I enjoyed writing that. 

Yeah, that was fun.

Are you still reading?

Wow. 

...Strange isn't it: the two of us, separated by time and space; sharing the internet... It totally violates the social cluster dynamics of the real world. I have no idea who you are. To me, you're just an empty category. A space to be filled. To you, I'm just the origin of a set of words, some of which form a kind of argument of interrelated claims and observations. Still, you know almost nothing about me. 

I wonder how accurately you'd guess what kind of person I am.

author: Connor Wilcox
comment:
There’s some really good tips here and some really misleading ones. Sounding articulate doesn’t come from using a bunch of really obscure words whenever possible, it comes from using your surface lexicon as efficiently as possible. 

Slang is the definition of efficiency, packing a lot of meaning into a widely understood word to get your point across more quickly. The only issue that comes about with slang and vulgarity is when a word represents too many distinct ideas and there’s no way to differentiate which is being used based on the context surrounding the word (i.e. did you see that jawn yesterday?). As long as the context surrounding the word narrows it’s meaning down to something understandable by others, there’s no reason to avoid using it other than arbitrary social pressures.

Overall, I think the best mindset to have is not to try to sound a particular way for the sake of others’ perception of you, but to use your words effectively and efficiently to communicate your ideas clearly and not waste others’ time.

author: ddevvnnull
comment:
So, if I understood you correctly, to summarize:

1. Broadening one's surface lexicon/your go-to daily reserve of vocabulary.
2. Cultivating a deep(er) lexicon. The reserve that requires more attention and discernment compared to your surface lexicon.
3. Abstaining from filler words. They bog down a conversation and compromise the quality of your speech. Recursively refining your speech by saying words first without understanding the endpoint of your statement is one version of this problem.
4. Observing and improving your language inputs. What you read and listen to, including passively, has an influence on your own speech. Try to imbue your language inputs with refined literature, poetry, enhanced speech, and the like.
5. Don't underestimate the efficiency of your vocals. Your speed, pauses, volume, and other aspects of vocalized speech can leave an undeniable impression on others. 

Great video. Thanks for sharing.
